subject: Probability – Large Deviations
title: Large Deviations (TUM, Module MA5417)
description: Large-deviation theory for unlikely events and exponential decay of probabilities; i.i.d. sequences and empirical measures; applications in ergodic theory, information theory, and statistical physics. Workload 150 h (45 h contact), 5 ECTS, offered irregularly. Version 2021s responsible: Gantert, Nina.

goals.title: Large Deviations – Module Overview
goals.description: Learner masters core large-deviation principles for i.i.d. sequences and empirical measures and can apply exponential estimates in typical applications.
goals.descriptionEn: Learner masters core large-deviation principles for i.i.d. sequences and empirical measures and can apply exponential estimates in typical applications.

goals.title: Foundations & Exponential Inequalities
goals.description: Learner can explain the purpose of large-deviation theory, state exponential inequalities, and relate decay rates to unlikely events.
goals.descriptionEn: Learner can explain the purpose of large-deviation theory, state exponential inequalities, and relate decay rates to unlikely events.

goals.title: LDP for i.i.d. Sequences
goals.description: Learner can formulate and apply large-deviation principles for sums of i.i.d. random variables, including rate functions.
goals.descriptionEn: Learner can formulate and apply large-deviation principles for sums of i.i.d. random variables, including rate functions.

goals.title: LDP for Empirical Measures
goals.description: Learner can state and use large-deviation results for empirical measures and interpret rate functions in this context.
goals.descriptionEn: Learner can state and use large-deviation results for empirical measures and interpret rate functions in this context.

goals.title: Applications in Ergodic/Info Theory & Physics
goals.description: Learner can apply large-deviation techniques to examples from ergodic theory, information theory, and statistical physics.
goals.descriptionEn: Learner can apply large-deviation techniques to examples from ergodic theory, information theory, and statistical physics.

descriptionEn: Large-deviation theory for unlikely events and exponential decay of probabilities; i.i.d. sequences and empirical measures; applications in ergodic theory, information theory, and statistical physics. Workload 150 h (45 h contact), 5 ECTS, offered irregularly. Version 2021s responsible: Gantert, Nina.
